These regulations, in principle, have been given their broad outlines in the Al-Quran and Hadith. Therefore, everything related to all social affairs must not contradict the principles that have been determined. Therefore, all regulations concerning the interests of the ummah must not be betrayed, and must be obeyed as they should be. Almost all activities in society are related to that trust. That is why Allah forbids Muslims from betraying trusts, because if trusts are no longer maintained, it means that trust is lost. If trust is lost, it means that legal order will no longer be maintained and the tranquility of community life cannot be enjoyed.

Allah affirms that the danger that will befall society because of betraying trusts that have been known, both the danger that will befall them in this world, namely the rampant evil and immorality that shakes community life, or the eternal regret and the torment of hellfire that will befall them in the hereafter.

Betrayal is the characteristic of the hypocrites, while trustworthiness is the characteristic of the believers. So a believer must avoid the trait of betrayal so as not to be infected with the disease of hypocrisy that can erode his faith.

Anas bin Malik said:

"The Messenger of Allah (saw) always said in every sermon: "He who cannot be trusted has no faith, and he who cannot be trusted has no religion." (Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Hibban from Anas bin Malik)

The Prophet (saw) said:

"The signs of a hypocrite are three. When he speaks, he lies, and when he makes a promise, he breaks it, and when he is entrusted, he betrays." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.28:
Allah warns the Muslims to know that their wealth and children are a trial. The meaning is that Allah bestows wealth and children upon the Muslims as a test for them, whether that wealth and many children increase their piety towards Allah, their gratitude for His blessings, and their fulfillment of rights and obligations as determined by Allah. If a Muslim is given wealth by Allah, and then he is grateful for that wealth by spending it according to Allah's provisions, it means he is fulfilling the obligations that Allah has determined for them. But if, with the wealth they obtain, they become more greedy and try to increase their wealth through unlawful means and are reluctant to spend their wealth, then such a person is one who denies Allah's blessings.

In human life in society, wealth is a source of pride in worldly life. People often forget that wealth is only a trust from Allah entrusted to them, so they are mostly attracted to wealth and forget the obligations that must be carried out.

Likewise, children are one of the pleasures of life and become a source of pride for someone. This is also a trial for the Muslims. Children must be educated with good education so that they become righteous children. If someone succeeds in educating their children according to religious demands, it means that the child becomes a blessing of inestimable value. However, if the child is left to follow his desires, unwilling to carry out religious commands, then this becomes a disaster, not only for his parents, but even for the entire community. Therefore, it is obligatory for a Muslim to protect himself from these two trials. He should control wealth and children to be used and educated in accordance with religious demands and stay away from the disasters caused by wealth and children.

Allah affirms that indeed with Allah is a great reward. The meaning is that whoever prioritizes Allah's pleasure over loving his wealth and children, then he will receive a great reward from Allah. Allah's warning so that humans do not forget religious provisions because of abundant wealth and many children is also mentioned in another verse.

Allah says:

"O you who have believed, let not your wealth and your children divert you from remembrance of Allah. And whoever does that - then those are the losers." (al-Munafiqun/63: 9)
text.29:
Allah calls upon those who believe that if they are pious to Allah, that is, they protect themselves by carrying out what He has established based on Allah's laws and avoid all kinds of prohibitions, such as not wanting to betray, prioritizing His laws, Allah will give them guidance that can distinguish between what is right and what is wrong, and that guidance will be a helper for them in times of trouble and a light in times of darkness.

Allah says:

"O you who have believed, fear Allah and believe in His Messenger (Muhammad) that He may grant you a double portion of His mercy and make for you a light by which you will walk and forgive you. And Allah is Forgiving and Merciful." (al-Hadid/57: 28)

Allah promises them that He will erase all their mistakes and forgive their sins because they are pious, and they will also be given *furqan*, so that they can know which actions should be avoided because they are forbidden by Allah, and they can also protect themselves from things that lead to destruction. People who receive Allah's forgiveness mean they live happily. This can be achieved because of Allah's grace alone.

Allah affirms that Allah has great bounty because He is the One who can give virtue to His creatures, both virtue to His servants in this world or *maghfirah* and His Paradise which is given to His beloved servants in the Hereafter.
text.30:
Allah reminds Prophet Muhammad and his companions of an event they experienced while they were in Mecca. They were saved from the torment of the polytheists. At that time, the Quraysh infidels planned a deception to be carried out against the Prophet, namely to imprison the Prophet so that he could not meet with people and could no longer spread the religion of Islam, or to kill the Prophet in a way that would make it difficult for his tribe to seek revenge, so that it would not cause danger to whoever killed him, or to expel the Prophet and exile him to a remote place.

At that time, the Quraysh infidels were planning a deception. Allah gave His help to Prophet Muhammad, namely Allah thwarted their efforts by ordering the Prophet and his companions to migrate to Medina, so that the Prophet and his companions were spared from the deception of the polytheists.

Allah affirms that He is the best of those who plan, that is, He can defeat the deception of the polytheists and the Quraysh infidels who want to harm the Prophet.
text.31:
Allah explains the denial of the Quraysh people and their arrogance towards the Prophet's call, especially when hearing the verses recited by the Prophet. They responded with an arrogant attitude. They considered themselves capable of reciting like that. This statement was emphasized by an-Nadhar bin al-Haris from Bani Abdid Dar. He traveled back and forth to Persia and heard from them about Rustam and Isfandiar from several prominent non-Arabs. He often met with Jews and Christians, so he heard from them the contents of the Torah and the Gospel.

Then Allah explains the reasons why the Quraysh people put forward such assumptions, namely because they considered the verses of the Al-Quran recited by Prophet Muhammad and his followers to resemble the stories found in the Torah and the Gospel. That is why they felt capable of reciting the verses recited by the Prophet. They assumed that the verses recited by Muhammad were not revelation, but rather tales of ancient people.

However, it is possible that an-Nadhar uttered those words, and then others followed. But they did not believe that the verses recited were tales of ancient people, which were confusing, nor did they assume that Muhammad fabricated them, because they never accused Muhammad of being a liar.

Allah says:

"For indeed, they do not call you untruthful, but it is the verses of Allah that the wrongdoers deny." (al-Anam/6: 33)

And Allah says:

"And they say, "Legends of the former peoples which he has caused to be written down, and they are recited to him morning and afternoon." (al-Furqan/25: 5)

Actually, they did not disbelieve the truth of the verses, because they actually knew that Prophet Muhammad was *ummi* (unlettered), but they said so only to prevent people from listening to the Al-Quran.

There is also an opinion that the leaders of the Quraysh such as an-Nadhar bin al-Haris, Abu Jahal, and al-Walid bin Mugirah all agreed to tell people not to listen to the Al-Quran. Then they came to the Prophet's house at night to listen to it and they were attracted to the Al-Quran. Because the recitation of the Al-Quran was so impressive on their hearts that al-Walid bin Mugirah uttered the famous words, "Indeed, the Al-Quran is of high value." That is why they prevented the Arabs from listening to the verses of the Al-Quran and kept the Arabs away from the Al-Quran, they said that the Al-Quran was magic.
text.32:
Allah reminds the believers of an event in which the disbelieving Quraysh opposed the Prophet Muhammad, saying that if the Qur'an disseminated by Muhammad was truly revealed from Allah, as claimed by the Prophet and made the basis of his religion, then the Quraysh asked Allah to provide proof to strengthen his words. They asked that stones be rained down from the sky or that they be given a painful punishment.

In this verse, there is an indication that the disbelieving Quraysh would not want to become followers of the Prophet Muhammad, even if what Muhammad said were truly verses revealed from Allah. This proves that they preferred destruction to believing in Muhammad. They asked Allah to rain stones from the sky or to punish them with a painful torment.
text.33:
Allah explains to the Muslims how they should respond to the actions of the polytheists. Allah commands the Muslims to disregard their attitude, because He will not fulfill their requests. Because these requests are not in accordance with Sunnatullah and are also not in accordance with the attributes of Allah, who is Most Wise and Most Merciful. Allah will not punish them in this world, because the Prophet was sent to give guidance to them, to make them aware of their disbelief, until they show remorse for their actions. The Prophet was sent as a mercy, not as a disaster. Allah will not punish them as long as the Messenger of Allah is among them. Allah will only punish them after the Messenger of Allah migrates to Medina.

Allah explains that He will not send down punishment upon them if they are willing to stop their denial and repent, that is, follow the guidance that has been given by the Messenger of Allah and they are willing to embrace Islam.
text.34:
After that, Allah explained that He would not send down punishment upon them, even though they deserved to be punished, because they had prevented the believers from entering the Masjidil Haram to perform the Hajj pilgrimage. The punishment was not sent down because the Prophet Muhammad was among them, and there were still believers who sought forgiveness from Allah along with the Prophet Muhammad.

Allah explained that the disbelievers did not have the right to control the House of Allah (Baitullah) and the sacred areas (haram), because they had committed shirk and had carried out various acts of corruption in that area. However, those who truly have the right to control the Baitullah and the sacred areas are only those who are pious (bertaqwa) who respect the Baitullah as a sacred place of worship, namely the Prophet Muhammad and his followers.

Allah affirmed that most of the disbelievers did not know that they did not have the right to control the Baitullah and the sacred areas, because they were not helpers of the religion. And those who have the right to control the Baitullah are only those who are pious (bertaqwa).
text.35:
Allah explains the reasons why they are not entitled to control the Baitullah, and the sacred territory, which is because during their worship, performing tawaf, they were naked and whistled and clapped their hands.

It is narrated from Ibn Abbas ra: "The Quraysh people circled the Baitullah in a state of nakedness, whistling and clapping their hands." (Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim from Ibn Abbas).

And he said:

"That the Quraysh people, both men and women, circled the Kaaba in a state of nakedness. They held hands, whistled and clapped their hands." (Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim from Ibn Abbas)

Ath-thasti narrates a narration that Nafi bin al-Azraq asked, saying to Ibn Abbas:

"Tell me about the meaning of the word of Allah Azza wa Jalla "Illa mukaan wa tashdiyah." He said, "Al-Muka is the sound of the Qunburah bird and Tashdiyah is the sound of the sparrow, the same as clapping hands. And that was when the Messenger of Allah was performing prayer, while he was in the place between the Hajar Aswad and the Rukun Yamani (that is, he was facing north in order to unite the direction of the Kaaba and Baitul Makdis in one direction of purpose). Then two men from Bani Sahm came, one standing to the right of the Prophet, while the other clapped his hands as loud as the sound of sparrows, disturbing the Prophet's prayer saw." (Narrated by Ath-thasti from Nafi bin Azraq)

Then Allah threatened their actions with a severe threat, in the form of punishment for their disbelief. This punishment includes worldly punishment and the punishment of the Hereafter. The worldly punishment they experienced was the death of their leaders and the capture of their soldiers at the time of the Battle of Badr, as well as their total defeat at the time of the conquest of Mecca. While their punishment in the Hereafter is endless regret when they feel the terrible suffering from the heat of hellfire.
text.36:
The commentators narrate from Ibn Abbas, Mujahid, Said bin Jubair, and others as follows, "This verse was revealed concerning Abu Sufyan and his wealth which was given to finance the polytheists at the time of the Battle of Badr, as well as his assistance to them at the time of the Battle of Uhud and others."

In another narration it is mentioned that, after Abu Sufyan was able to save his caravan (in the Battle of Badr) by taking the coastal road to Mecca, he walked with a platoon of the polytheist army inciting people not to fight them. Then they came to the people who had merchandise in the caravan, saying, "O people of Quraysh, know that Muhammad has isolated you and killed your leaders. So help us by sacrificing your wealth to fight Muhammad. Perhaps we can achieve victory over him." Then they carried out that suggestion. Said bin Jubir said, "Indeed, Abu Sufyan at the time of the Battle of Uhud hired 2,000 people from the Bani Kinanah tribe to fight the Messenger of Allah in addition to the Arabs who were already soldiers." (Narrated by Ath-thasti from Nafi bin Azraq)

In this verse, Allah explains the preparations of the disbelieving Quraysh people as the Battle of Badr approached, namely that they mobilized their energy and wealth to hinder the spread of the Islamic religion and the struggle of the Messenger of Allah.

No matter how much military strength they possessed and wealth they used, they would experience failure in spending that wealth, solely because their actions were like the actions of Satan that were not based on correct principles. The result is nothing but regret, because their strength of soul and wealth are lost without benefit and their struggle is in vain. Then their struggle will be broken successively, so that in the end only the word of Allah will prevail. Allah threatens the disbelievers with a severe threat, that on the Day of Judgment they will be driven into the fire of Hell.
text.37:
Allah explains that He will grant victory to the believers and defeat to the disbelievers. The intention is to separate the bad group from the good and to make the bad group an inseparable unity.

The good group is those who move under the auspices of the religion of monotheism (tauhid) and strive to elevate the word of Allah under the leadership of the Messenger of Allah to realize what is commanded by Allah and to destroy everything that hinders it. And to prevent everything that is forbidden by Allah and to destroy everything that causes the occurrence of that prohibition. They strive with energy, thought, and wealth for the benefit of religion. While the bad group is those who wallow in polytheism (kemusyrikan) and hinder the religion of Islam and violate the laws of Allah and ignite hostility and cruelty. The separation between these two groups is a continuous provision. And what is eternal is the good among the two groups.

Allah says:

"As for the foam, it vanishes, [passing away] as dross; but what benefits the people remains on the earth. Thus does Allah present examples." (ar-Rad/13: 17)

Allah also explains that the bad group will be piled up into one pile like useless things and they will be put into the fire of Hell. They are described by Allah as people who are truly losers because their wealth and souls are sacrificed to a futile struggle. They will experience regret that is no longer useful, because they cannot escape from Allah's very painful punishment.
text.38:
Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad and his followers to declare to the disbelievers of Quraysh, namely Abu Sufyan and his followers, that Allah was offering them a chance: if they would cease their hostility towards the call of the Prophet Muhammad and stop their deception in hindering the spread of Allah's religion, they would still be given an opportunity to repent. And Allah would forgive their sins that they had committed, and they would not experience torment in the Hereafter.

Likewise, the Messenger of Allah would not fight them and would not seek revenge for their actions that they had committed, whether in the form of torture, expulsion, murder, robbery, or others. This is a provision of Islam, which is to love peace as long as the teachings of Islam can spread on the face of the earth and are not hindered. However, if the call of the Islamic religion is hindered, then Muslims will take action against those who hinder it.

Allah gives a threat and warning that if they still ignore the call and remain steadfast in their hostility towards the teachings of Islam, and hinder and fight against the Muslims, then the sunnah of Allah that has been applied to the people of the past will be applied again, namely that Allah will help the struggle of the believers and destroy the deception of the disbelievers.

Allah says:

"Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during the life of this world and on the Day when the witnesses will stand." (al-Mumin/40: 51)

To illustrate that if the polytheists truly stopped their actions of hostility towards the Prophet Muhammad, accepted his call, and entered Islam, they would certainly receive forgiveness from Allah. As in the hadith narrated by Amr bin al-Ash, who said:

"After Allah had truly instilled the religion of Islam into my heart, I came to the Prophet and said: "Extend your hand, I will pledge allegiance to you." So the Messenger of Allah extended his right hand, then I withdrew my hand. The Prophet asked: "Why did you withdraw your hand?" I replied: "I will stipulate a condition." The Messenger of Allah asked: "What will you stipulate?" I replied: "I want Allah to forgive me." The Messenger of Allah said: "Do you not know, O Amr, that Islam erases what happened before it, and that the hijrah erases what came before it, and that hajj eliminates the sins that came before it?" (Narrated by Muslim from Amr bin al-Ash)
text.39:
Allah ignited the spirit of struggle in the believers, that is, if the polytheists continued to reject the call to cease hostilities, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah and his followers to fight them so that there would be no more *fitnah* that disturbed the Muslims and their religion. So that there would no longer be fear and anxiety gripping the heart of a person when entering Islam. This is a guarantee for humans that they have freedom in embracing religion and practicing its *sharia*.

Allah says:

"There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion. The right course has become clear from the wrong." (al-Baqarah/2: 256)

Then Allah offered once again to the polytheists that if they stopped their disbelief and hostility, then Allah is All-Seeing of what they do, and will give them recompense for their deeds.

The Messenger of Allah said:

"I have been commanded to fight the people until they say, "La ilaha illallahu." If they say that, they have protected their blood and property from me, except for a just cause, and their reckoning is with Allah Azza wa Jalla." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn Umar)

This command to fight is the last resort. There is another verse that encourages inviting to the right path with wisdom, as stated in Surah an-Nahl/16 verse 125.
text.40:
Allah threatens them that if they continue to reject the Prophet's call for peace and persist in their denial of his message, continuing to fight and antagonize the Muslims, then Allah commands the Muslims to inform them that Allah remains their protector and will help the Muslims. And Allah guarantees victory for the Muslims. And Allah forbids the Muslims from surrendering and fearing the challenge of the polytheists. At the end of the verse, Allah affirms to the Muslims that He is the best of Protectors. Therefore, those who seek His protection will not be disappointed. And indeed, this has always been the case in human life, from ancient times until the coming of Islam, that those who are righteous among His servants are the only ones who have the right to inherit the earth of Allah.

Allah says:

"And We have already written in the book [of Psalms] after the Reminder [of the Preserved Tablet] that the earth [of Paradise] is inherited by My righteous servants." (al-Anbiya/21: 105)
text.41:
In this verse, Allah explains the distribution of spoils of war according to Islamic law. The majority of scholars (jumhur ulama) are of the opinion that this verse was revealed in connection with the Battle of Badr and is the first verse concerning the distribution of spoils of war after the Battle of Badr. Allah explains that all *ghanimah* (spoils of war) obtained by the Muslims from the disbelievers in warfare must have one-fifth taken for Allah and the Messenger, namely for matters related to religion, such as the benefit of a *dai* (preacher) in spreading the message, establishing the symbols of religion, maintaining the Kaaba, and for the needs of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his household for one year. Then, from this one-fifth, it must also be given to his relatives. In this case, those considered relatives of the Prophet are only Bani Hasyim and Bani Muthalib, and not Bani Abdi Syams and Bani Naufal. Then it is also given to Muslims who need assistance, such as orphans, the poor, and *ibnussabil* (travelers who lack funds).

Four-fifths of the *ghanimah* is distributed to the soldiers who participated in the war. It is narrated by Imam al-Bukhari from Mutim bin Jubair from Bani Naufal, he said, "I, with Uthman bin Affan from the tribe of Bani Abdi Syams, came together to the Messenger of Allah, then we asked him, "O Messenger of Allah, you have given *ghanimah* to the tribe of Bani Muthalib and left us without a share, even though we are of the same rank as them." The Messenger of Allah replied, "Indeed, the tribe of Bani Muthalib and Bani Hasyim are one entity." This answer of the Messenger of Allah was an insinuation to Bani Syams and Bani Naufal, that they could not be equated with Bani Muthalib and Bani Hasyim who always struggled alongside the Messenger of Allah and never opposed him. Mujahid, a *tafsir* (Quranic commentary) expert, said that Allah knows that among the tribes of Bani Hasyim and Bani Muthalib, many are poor. Therefore, they were given a share of the *ghanimah*, because they are not allowed to receive *zakat* (obligatory charity).

The difference in treatment above must be traced back to history, namely when the Quraysh wrote a letter determining their attitude towards the Prophet Muhammad to boycott the Prophet's companions. So the Quraysh expelled Bani Hasyim from Mecca and placed them in the *shi'ib* (valley) of Bani Hasyim, because they always protected the Prophet Muhammad. Then the tribe of Bani Muthalib also joined them, while the tribes of Abdi Syams and Bani Naufal did not join them, so they were not boycotted by the Quraysh. Abu Sufyan from the descendants of Bani Umaiyah often fought against the Prophet Muhammad together with the polytheists and the Jews until Mecca was conquered by the Prophet Muhammad, and only then did Abu Sufyan embrace Islam.

As for the wisdom of distributing *ghanimah* for Allah and the Messenger, it is because the Islamic government in managing its people needs to have funds to be used for the common good, to uphold the symbols of religion, and for defense. All of that is taken from one-fifth for Allah. Then, for the interests of the head of state, a portion is given to the Messenger of Allah and his household. Then it is also given to his close relatives, namely Bani Hasyim and Bani Muthalib, as an appreciation for their support for the Prophet's struggle. Then also to people who need assistance, and Muslims who are economically weak. This method of distribution is always practiced in most Islamic countries, although there are slight differences in practice in dealing with the needs of the community and its people. This method of distribution must be accepted and implemented if Muslims truly believe in Allah and in what He has revealed.

The Battle of Badr is named *yaum al-furqan*. *Yaum al-furqan* is the day that separates between faith and disbelief. The victory of the Muslims in the Battle of Badr was the first victory against the polytheists, even though their number was three times greater than the Muslims. Allah is All-Powerful over all things, able to give victory to the Muslims according to His promise. The Battle of Badr, besides being called "*yaum al-furqan*," is also "*yaum iltaqa al-jam'an*," which means the day the two armies met, the Muslim army under the leadership of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the Quraysh army under the leadership of Abu Jahal and his companions.
text.42:
In this verse, Allah shows His mercy to the Muslims during the Battle of Badr. The Muslims occupied a very strategic location, highly conducive to achieving victory, namely choosing a place on the edge of the valley near Medina, while the polytheists were at the far end of the valley, far from the camel caravan carrying merchandise led by Abu Sufyan on the coast, about five miles from Badr. The Muslims were on the edge of the valley closest to Medina, when it had just rained, so they had a sufficient supply of drinking water and the ground was watered by rain, while the polytheists were at the far end of the valley, which was dry because it did not receive rainwater, and the ground trodden by the polytheists was dusty, so their feet easily sank.

If the Muslims had made an agreement to determine the time of battle, they would certainly not have agreed on determining that time. However, because Allah had determined the course of the battle, the timing was not planned by the Muslims themselves, especially considering that the number of Muslim soldiers was very small compared to the number of polytheist soldiers, and their weaponry was incomplete.

The intention of the Muslims in fighting was to seize the camel caravan full of merchandise brought from Syria under the leadership of Abu Sufyan. This action was in retaliation for the actions of the polytheists who had seized the property of the Muslims that they had left in Mecca because of their migration to Medina. Initially, the polytheists did not feel intimidated facing the Muslims led by the Messenger of Allah. But after they knew their position and condition, they felt intimidated facing the Muslims. Abu Sufyan, as the leader of the trade caravan, then sent a messenger to Mecca to inform them of the danger they faced. Then the Quraysh from Mecca sent troops led by Abu Jahl with the intention of helping Abu Sufyan's caravan. Knowing the arrival of a large Quraysh army from Mecca, the Prophet Muhammad changed direction from intercepting Abu Sufyan to facing the Quraysh army. Thus, the battle took place in the valley of Badr.

Allah brought the two armies together without prior agreement from either side to determine the battle. Allah willed victory for the Muslims and destruction for the polytheists, so that those who believe would achieve victory based on evidence that could be witnessed clearly as proof of the truth of Islam, and as proof that Allah had fulfilled His promise to His Prophet and the Muslims, so that their doubts would disappear and victory would turn out to be in the hands of the Muslims.

Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing of everything spoken by the disbelievers and the believers and will certainly give recompense according to what He hears and knows.
text.43:
Allah knows what the Prophet's companions said and also knows what was stored in their hearts when Allah showed the Prophet in a dream that the number of enemies was small. After the Prophet informed his companions about his dream, their hearts were at peace and their hopes for victory increased, so that the dream gave them encouragement and enthusiasm to face the battlefield.

If Allah had shown His Prophet that the number of polytheists was large, fear would have arisen in their hearts, they would have been afraid to face the enemy, and it would certainly have caused great conflict among the Muslims who did not agree to wage war, because among the Muslims there were those who were strong in faith and wanted to obey the Messenger's command to fight, and there were also those who were weak in faith, who wanted to avoid war. Allah saved the Muslims from fear and discord that could lead to weakness and destruction. Indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of what is stored in the heart, namely the feelings of fear and anxiety of those who are weak in faith and the courage to advance to the battlefield of those who are strong in faith and always trust in Allah.
text.44: In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet to be grateful for His blessings, when He showed the enemy in a small number in the Prophet's and the companions' sight. Similarly, Allah showed the number of the Muslim army to be small in the eyes of their enemies, so that both sides would advance to war with the hope of achieving victory. The Muslims fought with enthusiasm because their hearts were full of faith and trust in Allah's promise that they would achieve victory and be aided by angels. The disbelievers advanced, driven by feelings of arrogance and self-deception, so that Abu Jahl said, "The number of Muhammad's army is small, enough to be fed with just one camel." Because each group had the hope of winning, a fierce battle ensued, ending according to Allah's decree, which was victory for the Muslims.
text.45:
In this verse, Allah commands the Muslims, when they encounter the enemy forces, to strengthen their hearts and always remember Allah by frequently engaging in *dhikr*, so that they may gain steadfastness in battle, and not flee from the enemy. This is a strength that leads to victory in every struggle, whether as an individual or as an army. It is likened to a boxing or wrestling arena, where after grappling for some time, both boxers or wrestlers will feel tired and weak, each waiting for a moment or opportunity to knock down their opponent. However, sometimes it also crosses their mind that their opponent will be overcome with fear, so they persevere, maintaining steadfastness until the final round, declared the winner even if only by points. Similarly, in every battle between armies, what leads to superiority and victory is the steadfastness of the soldiers and not giving up hope. Steadfastness is very useful in every struggle.

Allah commands the Muslims to increase *dhikr* to Allah when facing war by always remembering His power and His promise to give help to His Messenger and the Muslims. In every struggle, Muslims must be certain that victory is in the hands of Allah and Allah will give it to whomever He wills. *Dhikr* is done by reciting the *takbir* "Allahu Akbar" or offering sincere prayers and believing that Allah Almighty can grant victory. Steadfastness and frequent *dhikr* to Allah are two very important things to achieve the goal.
text.47:
In this verse, Allah forbids the Muslims from behaving like the disbelieving Quraysh who left their homes with arrogance, intending to show off to people. They acted arrogantly and haughtily towards those who saw them, and they always praised their army, highlighting their heroic and courageous attitudes. They intended to provoke hostility towards the Prophet Muhammad and turn away from his da'wah (call to Islam), and to persecute the companions who followed in the Prophet's footsteps. Allah warns that He is All-Knowing of what they do and threatens them with a punishment commensurate with their evil deeds.

According to Imam al-Bukhari, this verse was revealed in connection with the event of the polytheistic Quraysh, when they left the city of Mecca and moved towards Badr. When the Messenger of Allah faced the polytheistic army, he supplicated, saying, "O Allah, here are the Quraysh who have come with pride and arrogance, they disbelieve in You and deny Your messenger, so grant us the victory that You have promised us." When Abu Sufyan, who was leading the trade caravan of camels, saw that his camels had safely skirted the coast, he said to Abu Jahl, who was leading the Quraysh army, "Your coming was only to save the camel caravan from being seized by Muhammad's companions, and now the camel caravan is safe. Therefore, return to Mecca." Abu Jahl said, "By Allah, we will not return before reaching Badr." Coincidentally, at that time there was a large market in Badr that gathered many goods every year. Abu Jahl said, "We will stay in Badr for three days so that we can drink wine to our satisfaction, eat delicious food, slaughter camels, and entertain ourselves with songs and art. Let all the Arab nations know and witness that the Quraysh are in greatness and glory." Therefore, Allah forbids the Muslims from behaving like them; instead, the believers must maintain sincerity of heart, steadfastness, patience, and obedience to the Messenger of Allah.
text.48:
In this verse, Allah commands the Muslims to pay attention to the events experienced by the polytheists with Satan during the Battle of Badr, namely when Satan made them see their actions as good by saying that no human being could defeat them on that day and that Satan would continue to provide the necessary assistance. Satan made the Quraysh polytheists believe that they would surely win, that no group could defeat them, because of their large number of soldiers and complete weaponry. Satan also incited his followers by saying that their struggle was truly a holy struggle, and that Satan himself would remain with them as a loyal friend.

When the two armies faced each other so that each clearly saw the condition of their opponent, then before the battle took place, Satan turned back, saying, "Indeed, I am disassociated from you. Indeed, I see what you do not see." What Satan saw was Allah's reinforcements to the Muslims, namely an army of angels numbering no less than a thousand angels. Satan further said, "Indeed, I fear Allah, and Allah is severe in punishment."

Satan's fear was because he saw the angels who were sent down from the sky to help the struggle of the Muslims. Satan and the angels are two very opposing groups and cannot be together. If the two were to come together, then surely the stronger group, namely the angels, would destroy the weaker group, namely Satan and his companions.
text.49: In this verse, Allah warns the Muslims not to be influenced by the words uttered by the enemy, when the hypocrites and those with disease in their hearts said, "What on earth is driving Muhammad's companions to advance to the battlefield of Badr, even though their number is small, approximately three hundred people, and the number of their enemies is very large? Their courage is nothing but being deceived by their religion." Allah refutes their words with His saying, "Whoever puts his trust in Allah and believes in Him with a sincere and steadfast heart, then Allah will surely give him help, and nothing can prevent Allah's will, because Allah is All-Powerful, All-Wise."
text.50: In this verse, Allah explains that if the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had seen with his own eyes the condition of the Quraysh disbelievers when their souls were taken by the angels, while striking their faces and backs, the Messenger would surely have been horrified to see that torment. In addition to the torments felt by their bodies, they also suffered pain from the rebuke of the angels who said, "Taste the punishment of the burning Fire." Actually, what Allah explains in this verse is a matter that belongs to the unseen (ghaib), humans cannot see and witness that torment. If they could see it, they would surely witness a terrible event, so that it could make the disbelievers flee from their disbelief, and the wrongdoers stop from their wrongdoing for fear of the consequences. According to a narration, the meaning of this verse is: the Muslims struck them from the front, while the angels struck them from behind during the Battle of Badr. This shows the miracle of the Prophet in facing the large Quraysh army.
text.51:
The torment they experienced was a consequence of their own deeds, namely their disbelief and injustice, both in words and actions. The term "hands" is used to denote the performance of actions, even though an action is sometimes carried out with hands or feet, senses, or intellect, because according to custom, the majority of human actions are carried out with the hands. Allah will not punish anyone except because of the sins and transgressions they themselves committed.

Indeed, Allah says, "O My servants, I have forbidden injustice to Myself and have forbidden it among you, so do not be unjust. O My servants, it is only your deeds that I will account for you. Whoever finds good, let him praise Allah, and whoever finds evil, let him not blame anyone but himself." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Dharr)
text.52:
The state of the Quraysh polytheists was similar to the state of Pharaoh and his followers, and the disbelievers before them. They denied the verses of Allah, so Allah retaliated by punishing them, because of their sins, with a punishment inflicted by the Almighty and All-Powerful Lord. It has become Sunnatullah that Allah punishes the disbelievers because of their sins, and that is what happened during the Battle of Badr. Allah gave help to His Messenger and the Muslims, and destroyed the disbelievers because of their sins. Allah is All-Powerful and severe in His punishment. No one can escape from the punishment that He has decreed. The Prophet Muhammad said:

"Indeed, Allah Taala gives respite (does not immediately punish) to the oppressor, but when He will punish him, then he will not escape from His punishment." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.53:
This event, namely the torment of the Quraysh, was because they denied Allah's blessings, when Allah sent a messenger from among themselves, who recited His verses, but they denied him, even expelling him from their land, and then continuously fought him. Allah punished them because of their sins. This proves the *sunnatullah* that has been in effect since ancient times. Allah does not change a blessing that He has bestowed upon a people until that people changes what is within themselves. This verse contains an indication that the blessings given by Allah to a people or individuals are always linked to the continuity of their own morals and deeds. If their morals and actions are well maintained, then Allah's blessings will remain with them and will not be withdrawn. Allah will not withdraw it without their injustice and transgression. However, when they have changed those blessings in the form of *aqidah*, morals, and good deeds, then Allah will change their condition and will withdraw His blessings from them, so that the rich become poor, the noble become humiliated, and the strong become weak. And the happiness of a people is certainly not linked to wealth or a large number of children, as thought by most of the polytheists, as narrated by Allah in His words:

"And they say, "We have more wealth and children than you, and we will not be punished."" (Saba/34: 35)

Likewise, the nobility of a people is not linked to their lineage or the virtue of their ancestors, as claimed by the Jews. They are deceived by their arrogance that they have been made by Allah as a chosen people above other peoples, because it is linked to the glory of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him). Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing of what is spoken by those who deny the messengers. He is All-Knowing of what they do, what they leave undone, and will surely give a reward commensurate with their deeds.
text.54: They changed the blessings of Allah that were upon them, like the behavior of Pharaoh and his followers, as well as the disbelievers before them. First, they denied the verses brought by the messengers concerning the Oneness of Allah, the obligation to worship only Allah, and the existence of Allah's punishment in the Hereafter. Second, they rejected the verses of Allah and denied His blessings, even though He is the One who created everything. Allah destroyed them because of their sins and drowned Pharaoh along with his followers because they were all wrongdoers (zalim).
text.55:
Indeed, the worst of living creatures in the sight of Allah are those who disbelieve, possessing the characteristic of stubborn defiance, so that their condition remains perpetually in disbelief and in denial of the Prophet, making it impossible to expect faith from them. Among them are those who hold positions of leadership, constantly envious of the Messenger of Allah, refuting every verse that is also written in the Torah, which testifies to his truthfulness, even though in their hearts they believe that Muhammad is truly a messenger of Allah, recognizing the Prophet Muhammad as they recognize their own children. Their followers are those who blindly follow their leaders and refuse to see the evidence mentioned in their scripture. In this verse, Allah likens them to animals, even more misguided than animals, because animals have benefits for humans, while they have no benefit whatsoever for themselves or for others. This is explained by Allah in His saying:

"Or do you think that most of them hear or understand? They are not but like livestock; rather, they are [even] more astray in [their] way." (al-Furqan/25: 44)
text.56:
The Jews had made agreements with the Muslims several times, but they always betrayed their promises and they did not fear Allah or the consequences of that betrayal.

After the Prophet Muhammad migrated to Medina, he made an agreement with the Jews in Medina. In that agreement, they were allowed to reside in Medina while adhering to their religion, and they were given security for themselves and their property. With this, the Prophet helped maintain the security of Medina from enemies. However, each Jewish tribe violated the agreement.

It is narrated from 'Abdullah bin 'Abbas that the Jews of Medina who broke the promise were the tribe of Bani Quraidhah. They had violated their promise to the Messenger of Allah, because they provided weapons to the disbelieving Quraysh during the Battle of Badr. Then they said, "We forgot and felt we had made a mistake." Then the Messenger of Allah made a second agreement, but it was also violated by inciting people to fight the Messenger of Allah during the Battle of Khandaq. One of their leaders deliberately went to Mecca to make an agreement with the Quraysh to fight against the Prophet Muhammad together.
text.57:
Allah explains what the Muslims must do after the repeated violations of promises by the Jews. Allah explains that if the Muslims encounter them in battle, they must be scattered, and those behind them must also be eradicated so that they may learn a lesson from the actions of the Jews. The firm action of the Muslims towards them must create a frightening impression on those behind them, so that they no longer dare to break their promises.

In this verse, Allah also warns the Muslims not to be deceived a second time after being betrayed the first time by the Jews and they asked for forgiveness. So Allah clearly explains that the Muslims should not hesitate to take firm action so that such violations are not repeated in the future and so that those behind them may learn a lesson from it.

It is narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim that the Prophet Muhammad once preached to his companions in the face of battle as follows:

"O people, do not desire (wish) to meet the enemy and ask Allah for safety. But when you meet them, then persevere with patience (in battle), and know that Paradise is under the shadow of the sword." Then he added with a prayer, "O Allah, who revealed the Qur'an, and who moves the clouds in the sky, destroy these enemy groups. Scatter them and grant us help to defeat them."
text.58:
If Muslims sense signs of betrayal from a group that has a defense agreement, the agreement must be returned to them, and they should strive to prevent the betrayal from occurring. This should be done by returning the agreement honestly, accompanied by a warning that after the betrayal, the Muslim side will no longer be bound by any promises to them. Allah does not like those who betray, nor does He permit betrayal in an absolute sense.

Muslims are forbidden from fighting them before there is notification that the agreement between them and the opposing side is no longer valid due to the betrayal. This needs to be announced so that there are no accusations from the enemy that Muslims have fought them without cause or violated the agreement. Allah also warns those who betray with a punishment that will befall them as a result of their betrayal.
text.59: And let not the disbelievers think that they can escape the power of Allah, and be safe from the consequences of their evil and treachery, for indeed they cannot weaken Allah at all. On the contrary, Allah will give them retribution in this world by being defeated by the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims, so that they feel the consequences of their treachery, and in the Hereafter they will feel a more humiliating punishment from Allah.
text.60:
To confront the treachery of the Jews and their conspiracy with the polytheists with the aim of destroying the Muslims, Allah commanded in this verse that the Muslims prepare strength to face the enemies of Islam, both enemies they clearly know and those who have not openly declared their hostility. What must be cultivated first is the strength of faith that will make them believe and be certain that they are defenders of the truth, upholders of the word of Allah on earth, and that they will surely be victorious in facing and eradicating injustice and wickedness. This perfect strength of faith is what can build mental strength that is always instilled in the hearts of all people so that they truly become a resilient and mighty nation in facing various kinds of difficulties and trials. A nation with strong mental fortitude cannot be defeated by another nation, no matter how perfect their equipment and weapons. This has been proven in the Battle of Badr, where the army of the polytheists, which was far greater in number and weaponry, could be repelled by the Islamic army, which was small in number and very lacking in weaponry, but possessed strong mental fortitude and unwavering faith.

In addition to their faith/mental strength, physical strength must also be prepared because these two strengths must be combined into one; physical strength alone will be less effective if it is not accompanied by mental strength. Likewise, mental strength alone will be powerless if it is not supported by physical strength.

Allah commanded the Muslims to prepare a cavalry army stationed in strategic locations, ready to crush and destroy any enemy attacks from wherever they come. In the time of the Prophet, this cavalry force was of great strategic value and great effectiveness. A country that has a large cavalry force will be respected by other countries, and those other countries will think twice before attacking that country.

In the present era, the cavalry has been replaced by armored tank forces; the nature and form of warfare today is different from the warfare of the past. The weapons used are also diverse, in the form of air fleets, naval fleets, and even the use of very sophisticated weaponry. If in the time of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), Allah commanded to prepare a cavalry force, then in the present era, Muslims must prepare various modern weapons to defend their country from enemy attacks.

As is known, modern weapons today are the result of technological advancements. Therefore, Muslims are obligated to strive to achieve the highest possible level of knowledge and master technology and always follow its developments and progress. To achieve high levels of knowledge and technology, we need very large costs. We must accelerate economic progress and increase people's income. This will make it easy for people to spend some of their wealth for the interests and defense of their country.

A country that is strong in mental fortitude, strong in defense, and strong in its economy will surely be respected by other countries, and they will not dare to antagonize it, let alone attack it. This is what Allah demands from the Muslims.

The encouragement to spend wealth *fi sabilillah* is found in several verses in the Al-Qur'an, including the word of Allah:

"And spend in the way of Allah and do not throw [yourselves] with your [own] hands into destruction [by refraining]. And do good; indeed, Allah loves the doers of good." (al-Baqarah/2: 195)

And the word of Allah swt:

"And the example of those who spend their wealth seeking means to the approval of Allah and assuring [thereby] themselves is like a garden on high ground which is hit by a downpour and yields its fruits in double measure. And [even] if it is not hit by a downpour, then a drizzle [is sufficient]. And Allah, of what you do, is Seeing." (al-Baqarah/2: 265)

Allah promises a great reward to everyone who spends their wealth in the way of Allah, and they will not be harmed in the slightest because of spending their wealth. On the contrary, that action will receive a multiple reward.
text.61:
If the enemies of Islam, whether Jews or polytheists, incline towards peace, perhaps because they genuinely desire peace, or because they see the strength and unity of the Muslims, or because they have not yet consolidated themselves for war, or for other reasons, then the possibility of peace should be explored. After it becomes clear that making peace will not harm the strategy of the Islamic struggle, then that peace should be accepted, of course with provisions and conditions that can guarantee mutual interests and not harm either party, because the basis of the Islamic struggle is peace. This was practiced by the Messenger of Allah when he accepted the Peace of Hudaybiyah between the Muslims and the polytheists in the sixth year of the Hijri. Although the conditions of the Peace of Hudaybiyah, at first glance, were detrimental to the Muslims, so that many of the Companions felt objections, the Messenger of Allah, who had a far-sighted view and wise tactics and strategies, was able to accept it. It later turned out, as stated by historians, that the Peace of Hudaybiyah was the foundation for the subsequent victory of the Muslims.

After the peace agreement is accepted, the Prophet and the Muslims should put their full trust in Allah, because He is the All-Hearing and All-Knowing of the true essence of peace, whether the Jews and polytheists are truly honest and desire the implementation of peace, or only because of tactics and strategies, or because they intend to deceive or wait for the Muslims to be negligent.
text.62:
If the Jews and the polytheists intended to deceive or seek an opportunity to attack under the guise of peace, then Allah guaranteed Prophet Muhammad saw that this would not harm the Muslims. Allah is sufficient (as a protector), Allah always protects His Messenger and protects the Muslim community and will grant them victory if the enemies attack again. Allah has strengthened the position of His Messenger with the help He gave to the Muslims in the past, as happened in the Battle of Badr, where the Muslims were weak and few in number. They were able to defeat the polytheists who were many times greater in number and fully armed. Allah has united the hearts of the Muslims so that they live in harmony and peace, loving each other, and helping each other, so that they are an inseparable unity, even though they previously lived in tribes and were hostile to each other. They initially consisted of the Muslims who came to Medina and the Ansar, the residents of Medina who welcomed the arrival of the Muslims. The Ansar themselves were previously divided into the Aus and Khazraj tribes. There was always hostility and war between these two tribes. But by the will of Allah, they all became a united community under the banners of faith, willing to sacrifice their wealth and lives to uphold the word of Allah. This is an invaluable gift from Allah that cannot be achieved even by sacrificing all wealth and possessions. Unity of heart, unity of determination, and unity of ideals and ideology are very important and valuable for achieving a goal. This is the gift of Allah that the Muslims possessed at that time. Because of the importance of that gift and its high value, Allah reminds them to always remember Allah with His word:

And remember the favor of Allah upon you - when you were enemies and He brought your hearts together and you became, by His favor, brothers. (Ali 'Imran/3: 103)

So with the help of Allah and the unity of the Muslims and the love and affection that is woven between them, no matter how difficult and how great the danger that will befall, it will certainly be overcome and resolved. Allah also warns in this verse how high the value of unity is, so that if Prophet Muhammad himself spent all the wealth on earth to achieve it, he would certainly not succeed. But Allah has united their hearts with strong faith and high affection. This is a sign that Allah is pleased with the Muslims and approves of their struggle and they need not worry, indeed Allah is All-Powerful, All-Wise.
