text.64:
In this verse, Allah reiterates His guarantee to the Prophet Muhammad, that Allah will help him with the assistance of Muslims who truly believe and are fully convinced that Allah is with them. According to a narration from Ibn Abbas, this verse was revealed in connection with the conversion of Umar to Islam, following the Islam of 33 men and six women, as stated by Jubair (see Tafsir al-Kabir, Volume VIII, pp. 197-198). With that faith and conviction, their resolve would not be shaken by any event or threat. That faith and conviction are described by Allah in His word:

"(Namely) those who, when people said to them, "Indeed, the people have gathered against you, so fear them," it [only] increased them in faith, and they said, "Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs." (Ali 'Imran/3: 173)

Therefore, with the firm conviction and resolve generated by faith and Allah's guarantee, the Muslims were ready to accept Allah's commands, no matter how difficult or challenging, even if those commands meant facing many enemies or great danger.
text.65:
Allah commanded His Messenger to ignite the spirit of the Muslims to fight the enemy in battle. The Prophet implemented this command by encouraging his companions to advance into battle, as in the Battle of Badr. Even though the number of the Kafir Quraysh army from Mecca was very large, and their equipment was better, the Prophet encouraged the believers by saying, "Qumu ila jannatin 'ardzuha as-samawat wa al-ard (Rise up to a battlefield that provides a paradise as vast as the heavens and the earth)."

In this verse, Allah also affirms that the strength of the Muslim forces who truly believe and are fully reliant on Allah will be able to defeat the enemy's strength, even if they are ten times greater in number. If the Muslim forces consisted of only twenty soldiers, they could defeat an enemy force of two hundred. If their forces consisted of one hundred people, they could defeat an enemy force of one thousand, and so on; each soldier of Allah could defeat ten enemies. This is a comparison of strength that is unparalleled in history, because the way of warfare at that time was not like warfare today.

Warfare today is highly dependent on the strength and perfection of weaponry. A small force, equipped with powerful modern weapons, can easily defeat a large force that only has ordinary weapons.

Warfare at that time was truly about pitting strength and skill against each other because the war tools used were arguably of the same type and quality. It would seem impossible for a small force to be able to win against a large force that is ten times its size. But this is what Allah affirmed or commanded to the Muslims. They should not feel intimidated or afraid of facing opponents who are many times their number, because they are believers who are fighting not for their own interests, or to seek wealth and worldly glory, but they are soldiers of Allah who are fighting to defend the truth; to exalt the word of Allah and for the glory of the religion that He has approved. If they fall in battle, they will die as martyrs, the reward for which is invaluable in the sight of Allah.

The opponents of the Muslims are disbelievers who only want to defend their position, rank, and possessions. They do not have a high and noble purpose in life because they do not believe in the One God and do not believe in the Day of Resurrection. Their lives are only for boasting and prioritizing material possessions. As for the Jews in Medina, although they believe in the One God, they can no longer see the truth, because their eyes have been blinded by worldly pleasures. They want to live, if possible, for a thousand years; they have sunk into materialism, unable to escape the nature of greed and avarice. Both of these groups have truly strayed from the path of truth, no longer able to distinguish between what is right and what is wrong; they no longer know the path that leads to happiness in this world and the hereafter. People with such characteristics, when faced with a fierce battle, will run away in disarray because they prioritize life over death. This is explained by Allah in His word:

"Indeed, you [believers] are more feared in their breasts than Allah. That is because they are a people who do not understand." (al-Hashr/59: 13)

If Allah commands the Muslims to bravely face the enemies of Allah who number ten times their number and declares that they will win, then that victory is certain, even if it has never happened before in history. Therefore, they must not flee from battle and must fight to the death until victory is achieved. This is the highest degree that can be achieved by the Muslims.
text.66:
In this verse, Allah grants leniency to the Muslims in facing enemies who attack them. If in verse 65, Allah commanded them to bravely face enemies who numbered ten times greater than their own number, then in this verse it is explained that they are given leniency because they are in a state of weakness, both in spirit and in war preparations. In such a state, they are required to face enemies who number twice their own number. This is a minimum level that they must maintain, because the leniency given is already very significant compared to the original command, and there is no reason to ask for more leniency. With strong faith, perseverance, and full confidence in achieving victory. This was proven when they faced the polytheists in the Battle of Badr. Their strength was less than a third of the enemy's strength, but they were able to destroy the polytheists.

In the Battle of Yarmuk, the number of soldiers gathered by Emperor Heraclius of the Eastern Roman Empire to face the Muslim army was no less than 200,000 (two hundred thousand) people, while the Muslim army sent by the Companions was only 24,000 (twenty-four thousand) people. Thanks to their firm, strong faith and high spirit, the Muslims were able to defeat the numerous enemy. It is narrated that the number of Roman soldiers who died in that battle was 70,000 (seventy thousand) people. All the victories obtained by the Muslims were in accordance with the will and permission of Allah as proof of this truth. Allah says:

"How many a small company has overcome a large company by permission of Allah. And Allah is with the patient." (al-Baqarah/2: 249)
text.67:
This verse serves as a rebuke to the Prophet's decision to accept ransom from the polytheists in exchange for freeing their people who had been captured by the Muslims. He leaned towards the opinion of most of the companions who suggested that the prisoners not be killed, and that it would be better to accept ransom money from them, which could then be used for the sake of the struggle and war preparations in case the enemy attacked again. Therefore, Allah affirms in this verse that it is not appropriate for a Prophet in a battle to hold prisoners and await a decision, whether they will be released just like that or by accepting ransom from their families, unless the situation of his followers is strong and the enemy is powerless. The condition of the Muslims before the Battle of Badr was still weak, and their strength was still too small compared to the strength of the polytheists. If the prisoners were not killed, but instead released even after paying ransom, while they were the leaders and chiefs of their people, they would certainly return to incite and gather a large force to attack the Muslims. This was very dangerous for the position of the Muslims who were still weak. They should not have been taken prisoner, but rather killed directly on the battlefield, so that with the death of the dignitaries and leaders, the polytheists would be afraid and no longer dare to attack the Muslims. Allah says in Surah Muhammad/47: 4):

"So when you meet those who disbelieve [in battle], strike [their] necks until, when you have inflicted slaughter upon them, then secure their bonds, and either [confer] favor afterwards or ransom [them] until the war lays down its burdens. That [is the command]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken vengeance upon them [Himself], but [He ordered armed struggle] to test some of you by means of others. And those who are killed in the cause of Allah - He will never render their deeds worthless." (Muhammad/47: 4)

This verse is not only a rebuke to the Prophet Muhammad, but also a rebuke to the companions and most of the Muslims who suggested that the prisoners not be killed, because they were relatives and family, and might later become believers, especially since their ransom money could be used for their own benefit. With this suggestion, they had taken an action that contradicted war strategy. Whatever reasons they put forward, they had been influenced by worldly possessions, and without realizing it, they had forgotten and no longer considered the consequences of implementing that suggestion. Therefore, Allah explicitly states that they desire worldly possessions and life, while Allah wants them to seek reward in the Hereafter by striving in His way, exalting His word until the glory and height of His religion is achieved, as mentioned in His word:

"But honor [in victory] belongs to Allah and to His Messenger and to the believers..." (al-Munafiqun/63: 8)

This is the way Allah wants for those who believe and strive with their wealth, and all the abilities they have, even with their lives, to achieve it. Allah will always help them. Indeed, Allah is Almighty, All-Wise.
text.68:
In this verse, Allah explains that the actions of the Muslims in accepting the ransom were incorrect. If not for Allah's prior decree that He would not inflict punishment upon them for that error, they would have certainly received a severe torment.

Regarding what is meant by "Allah's prior decree to save the Muslims from punishment for that mistake," the commentators (mufassirun) cite several verses, including Allah's statement:

"But Allah would not punish them while you, [O Muhammad], are among them, and Allah would not punish them while they seek forgiveness." (al-Anfal/8: 33)

Although this verse concerns the polytheists, the Muslims are more deserving of that decree. While the misguided and disobedient polytheists could be saved from Allah's punishment by the presence of the Prophet among them, how much more so the Muslims who are obedient and loyal, always helping the Prophet and always seeking forgiveness from Allah; surely they are more worthy of not being afflicted with that severe punishment. Allah's statement:

"Your Lord has decreed upon Himself mercy: that any of you who does wrong out of ignorance and then repents after that and corrects himself - indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful." (al-An'am/6: 54)
text.69:
Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Merciful towards His servants. With these noble attributes, Allah forgives and does not inflict punishment upon the Muslims. Instead, He grants them the right to consume and possess the spoils of war obtained in battle, including the ransom money, as mentioned in the following narration:

It is narrated that initially, the Muslims were reluctant to use the ransom money paid by the polytheists, fearing they would err again if there was no revelation permitting them to utilize it. Then this verse was revealed. This is further proof of Allah's mercy and compassion towards them. After committing a mistake, they were forgiven and freed from punishment for that mistake. Furthermore, they were permitted to consume and possess the proceeds of that wrong action, namely the ransom money they received from the prisoners. Allah affirms that the wealth obtained from redeeming prisoners is lawful and good, unlike pork and carrion. Then Allah commands them to always be mindful of Him by carrying out all His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions, for He is the Most Forgiving and Most Merciful.
text.70: This verse commands the Messenger of Allah to say to the prisoners who feel burdened to spend their wealth to ransom themselves that Allah will replace the wealth they surrender with something better and purer, and to believe in Allah. Allah will forgive all sins, including shirk, hostility towards Muslims, hostility towards Islam, the religion He is pleased with, and committing various actions that displease Him. Allah is the Most Forgiving and Most Merciful towards His servants.
text.71:
With the explanation given by the Messenger of Allah to the prisoners as commanded by Allah, many of them declared their conversion to Islam and no longer opposed the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the Muslims. But Allah warned and gladdened the Prophet's heart regarding their subsequent attitude by explaining in this verse that if any of them betrayed their promise by returning to disbelief or attacking the Muslims, then the Prophet need not be upset or saddened. This is common and often happens to people. When in a difficult and desperate situation, they utter sweet words and make grand promises, but when in a safe and good environment, they deny all their promises and turn into even more evil enemies.

Such is the nature of some of the polytheists, because that nature has become ingrained in their very being. They have betrayed Allah, the Almighty and All-Powerful, by associating partners with Him, worshipping idols, and doing deeds that are not pleasing to Him. Because of this betrayal against Allah, He gave victory to the Muslims, as happened in the Battle of Badr, even though the polytheists were greater in number and had more complete weaponry. Allah is All-Knowing of everything that is hidden in their hearts, and All-Wise in giving recompense for what people do, the good is rewarded with blessings and the bad is rewarded with punishment.
text.72:
In this verse, three groups of Muslims are mentioned:

The first group is the one that obtains the highest and most noble degree in the sight of Allah, namely the Muhajirin who migrated with the Prophet Muhammad saw to Medina and those who followed later, namely those who migrated before the Battle of Badr. Then, some scholars of tafsir are of the opinion that this group also includes those who migrated before the Hudaibiyah peace treaty in the 6th year of Hijri. This first group, in addition to their struggle in Medina together with the Ansar, had also struggled previously in Mecca facing the cruel polytheists, who did not hesitate to commit violence and persecution against those who believed in the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad saw. All the violence and cruelty inflicted on the Muhajirin was received with patience and steadfastness and could not shake their faith in the slightest. They remained steadfast and struggled to defend the true religion and were willing to sacrifice their wealth and lives, even willing to leave their homeland, children, wives, and possessions. Therefore, they were given special designations by Allah, first: "Believing," second: "Migrating," third: "Striving with wealth and possessions in the way of Allah."

The second group is the "Ansar" in Medina who embraced Islam, believed in the Prophet saw, and they promised the Prophet and the Muhajirin that they would struggle together in the way of Allah, willing to bear all the risks and suffering of the struggle, for which they were ready to sacrifice their wealth and lives. The Prophet Muhammad saw instilled a sense of Islamic brotherhood (ukhuwah Islamiah) between these two groups so that the Ansar regarded the Muhajirin as blood brothers, each group being able to inherit from the other. Allah gave them two designations, first: "Giving a place of residence" and second: "Helpers," because of this they are also called "Ansar." It is as if these two groups, because of the closeness of their relationship, have become one, so that there is no longer any difference in rights and obligations between them. Therefore, Allah has determined that the relationship between them is a relationship of close kinship, a relationship of loyal friends, each feeling obliged to help and assist the other when struck by a danger or disaster. They help each other, advise each other, and will not allow others to take care of their affairs. Only from among them will a leader be appointed if they need a leader to handle their affairs.

Sahabat (Companion) Anas narrated that the Messenger of Allah saw had bound the Muhajirin and the Ansar in an oath of allegiance in my house. This hadith was narrated by Anas to the person who asked about the hadith: "There is no oath of allegiance in Islam."

The third group is the group of Muslims who did not migrate to Medina. They remained in the land controlled by the polytheists, such as the believers who were in Mecca and several places around the city of Medina. They cannot be equated with the two groups of Muhajirin and Ansar because they are not in the midst of an Islamic society, but are in the midst of a polytheistic society. So the relationship between them and the Muslims in Medina cannot be equated with the relationship between the Muhajirin and Ansar believers in Islamic society. If the relationship between fellow believers in Medina is very close, even to the point of close kinship and descent, then the relationship with this third group is only bound by faith. If they are subjected to unfair treatment by the polytheists, then the Muslims in Medina are powerless to defend them because they are in the land of the polytheists, and the Muslims of Medina have no right to interfere in the internal affairs of the polytheists. If they had migrated, they would certainly be free from arbitrary and unfair treatment. As for the believers who are captured by the polytheists, they must be freed by the believers with all their might because their residence in the land of the polytheists is not of their own free will, but in a state of compulsion and unable to escape from there. But if this third group asks for help from the believers because they are oppressed and forced to abandon their religion or are suppressed and constantly prevented with violence from practicing Islamic law, then the Muslims are obliged to provide assistance to them, even if necessary by launching attacks and wars, unless there is a peace treaty or a non-aggression pact between the believers and the polytheists. Such is the relationship between the first two groups and this third group, which must be observed and practiced, and they must act in accordance with the provisions that Allah has established. Allah always sees and knows what His servants do (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim). As for the fourth group, it will be explained in verse 75.
text.73: In this verse, Allah affirms that all disbelievers, despite their differing religions and sects – for among them are polytheists, Christians, Jews, and so on – and despite the disagreements and sometimes animosity between themselves, can all be loyal allies to one another in various matters. Some of them become leaders for others, and sometimes they even agree to oppose and attack the Muslims, as happened during the Battle of the Trench (Khandaq). At the time this verse was revealed, it could be said that only polytheists and Jews were present in the Hijaz. The Jews often formed alliances with the polytheists and helped them in opposing the Muslims, even frequently betraying agreements, which led to them being fought by the Muslims and expelled from Khaybar to outside the city of Medina. Therefore, the Muslims must build a strong unity and never make loyal promises with them or entrust them with managing the affairs of the Muslims, because this will lead to great loss or disaster. Allah warns that if this is not heeded, then fitnah (tribulation/discord) and corruption will occur on earth.
text.74:
In this verse, Allah explains the superiority of the Muhajirin and Ansar over other Muslims. They are given the predicate of people who truly believe, that is, people whose faith is perfect. They have proven this with real actions since the revelation came to the Prophet Muhammad until the establishment of the Islamic government in Medina. The Ansar have sacrificed with all their ability, both with wealth and with their lives, to uphold the religion of Allah. If it were not for their full help and assistance, the Muhajirin would not have been able to build Islamic power perfectly. Thanks to the strong faith and unity between these two groups and the close cooperation between them, a great force was formed that could not be paralyzed by the enemies of Islam, even though their strength was many times greater. Because of their superiority, Allah promises them forgiveness for all the mistakes they made previously, and for them is also prepared in the Hereafter a never-ending sustenance, namely a paradise full of unparalleled blessings.

To explain the degrees of the first, second, and third groups who possess several virtues, Allah says:

"(And there is also a share in this booty) for the poor emigrants who were expelled from their homes and their possessions, seeking bounty from Allah and (His) pleasure, and helping (the cause of) Allah and His Messenger. Such are indeed the sincere." (al-hasyr/59: 8)

And the word of Allah:

"And (it is also for) those who had settled in Medina and had embraced the faith before them (the Muhajirin). They love those who emigrate to them, and have no desire in their hearts for that which has been given them (the Muhajirin), and give them (the Muhajirin) preference over themselves, even though they were in need of that. And whosoever is saved from his own covetousness, such are they who will be successful." (al-hasyr/59: 9)

And His word:

"And those who came after them say: "Our Lord! Forgive us and our brethren who have preceded us in faith, and put not in our hearts any rancour against those who have believed. Our Lord! You are indeed full of kindness, Most Merciful." (al-hasyr/59: 10)
text.75:
In this verse, the fourth group is mentioned: those who were late in embracing Islam, late in believing, and also late in migrating. However, despite this, they could participate in the struggle sincerely alongside the Muslims. They were also willing to sacrifice their wealth and lives like their friends who had embraced Islam earlier. Therefore, they are not categorized as "latecomers to heroism"; on the contrary, they can be categorized into the Muhajirin and Ansar, although their rank with Allah is not as high as the rank of the first and second groups.

To explain the high rank of the Muhajirin and Ansar, Allah says:

Not equal are those who spent (in the cause of Allah) and fought before the conquest (of Mecca), with those who did so thereafter. They are greater in rank than those who spent and fought afterwards. But to all Allah has promised good. And Allah is Acquainted with what you do. (al-hadid/57: 10)

And His saying again:

The first forerunners [in the faith] - among the Muhajirin and the Ansar - and those who followed them with good conduct - Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him, and He has prepared for them gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. That is the great success. (at-Taubah/9: 100)

As a conclusion to this verse, Allah explains the position of *ulul arham* (close relatives) compared to the position of Muslims in general. *Ulul arham* who are believers are closer to a person than other Muslims, whether from the Muhajirin or Ansar. Therefore, they are more entitled to receive help, solidarity, and manage various affairs. Therefore, it is obligatory to build relationships between them by helping each other, inheriting from each other, and appointing them as guardians in marriage, and so on. It is narrated that the Prophet Muhammad saw once said:

Start (doing good) with yourself, so provide for yourself first. If there is still something to spend, give it to your family. If there is still more after giving to your family, give it to your close relatives. And if there is still more after giving to your close relatives, then act like that, meaning there is someone more entitled than the other, and so on. (Riwayat an-Nasa'i dari Jabir)

In the Al-Qur'an, there are also many of Allah's words that prioritize the position of the closest relatives, namely parents, by mentioning them first, then followed by the closest, namely *ulul arham*, and so on, Allah's words:

And be good to parents, relatives, orphans, and the needy. And speak good words to people. (al-Baqarah/2: 83)

Prioritizing parents and close relatives in doing good does not mean that the Islamic religion teaches or allows nepotism. Nepotism greatly prioritizes siblings and close relatives and close friends by sacrificing the rights of others, both in the appointment of certain positions and in the provision of several facilities (conveniences) by setting aside others who are also entitled to them. Nepotism is actually forbidden by religion because it contradicts the principle of justice, because religion commands its adherents to always uphold it. Justice must be upheld towards oneself, towards parents, and close relatives. Allah's words in Surah an-Nisa/4: 135 affirm the following:

O you who have believed, be persistently standing firm in justice, witnesses for Allah, even if it be against yourselves or parents and relatives. Whether one is rich or poor, Allah is more worthy of both. So follow not [personal] inclination, lest you not be just. And if you distort [your testimony] or refuse [to give it], then indeed Allah is ever, with what you do, Acquainted. (an-Nisa/4: 135)

Thus is the relationship between believers and thus are their levels and degrees with Allah. This should be paid attention to as well as possible so that Muslims can live in peace and happiness, because the one who establishes this order is Allah, the All-Knowing of everything.
